Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: The client's supply of floor cleaner is running low, and the next cleaning is scheduled for a few days from now.
Story: I sat on the bus, my phone buzzing in my pocket. My mom had just texted, “Can we talk tonight? Dad’s been quiet lately.” I knew what she wanted—someone to listen, to reassure her that everything would be okay. I always tried to check in, to ask if things were alright at home, even when I was tired from work. But as I glanced at my work schedule, my mind jumped to my other responsibility. The Johnsons’ house was on my list for tomorrow, and I remembered seeing the nearly empty bottle of floor cleaner last time. If I didn’t remind them or pick some up myself, I wouldn’t be able to do my job properly. My boss expected me to manage these supplies, to keep everything running smoothly. I felt pulled in two directions—my parents needed me emotionally, but my job demanded my attention and organization. My heart ached with guilt, knowing I couldn’t give both roles what they needed at the same time. I stared out the window, torn, unsure which expectation I should meet first.
